results.title: A New approach to dental health
results.brief_description: Shows a multidisciplinary approach to the teaching of dental care in some English schools. Illustrates how reading, writing, mathematical and social skills, as well as knowledge of dental care, can be developed with this approach. Also notes parents’ reactions to this style of teaching.

results.title: A Nation of shopkeepers
results.creator_credit: British Productivity Council and World Wide
results.brief_description: Intelligent use of Method Study can help any trader, shopkeeper, distributor or manufacturer. The example of an ironmonger’s shop shows how analysis of work is applied to the retail trade, leading to lower costs, higher turnovers, less waste of time and money, and greater satisfaction to both staff and customers. How to keep the cost of changes of layout and method involved to a minimum.

results.title: A Most attractive man
results.creator_credit: Rivka Hartman, Gillian Coote, A Most Attractive Man Productions and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Dorian gets by on his looks, and lives off Frances, a single mother of three kids. He doesn’t contribute much to either her emotional or financial well being. Frances is running out of patience and Dorian’s looks are fading. Described as a “sardonic Australian love story” and made on a $50,000 budget this quirky short film won the Australian Film Institute Jury Award in 1982. Cast includes Carole Skinner, Grigor Taylor, Julie McGregor, Dennis Miller, Anna Volska, Cathy Downes, Anne Tenney, Rivka Hartman.

results.title: A Momentous occasion
results.brief_description: Using relics, old photographs and re-enacted sequences this film tells the story of Charles Todd and the construction of the Overland Telegraph Line between Adelaide and Port Darwin in 1872.

results.title: A Million pounds a day
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham, Peter Bradford, National Dairy Council and World Wide
results.brief_description: The history of the British dairy industry over the last 150 years. Old prints recapture the early days of this industry. Traces development in quality and distribution. Features of the high standard of todays dairy produce including the breeding of high-yield cattle strains, use of artificial insemination and prevention of disease; technological aids in large-scale processing and bottling of milk and cream, and in butter and cheese manufacture; and the provision of a dependable transport network. Presented by Richard Todd.
